question:
Directions:

Directions : In the following question, a set of sentences is given, which when properly sequenced, form a coherent paragraph. Arrange the sentences in the correct sequence and answer the questions that follow.

A. Since 1994, the Summer and Winter Olympic Games have been held separately and have alternated every two years.

B. From the 8th century B.C. to the 4th century A.D., the Games were held every four years in Olympia, located in the western Peloponnese peninsula, in honour of the god Zeus.

C. The first modern Olympics took place in 1896 in Athens, and featured 280 participants from 13 nations, competing in 43 events.

D. The 2020 Summer Olympics, delayed one year because of the COVID-19 pandemic, was held from July 23 to August 8, 2021 in Tokyo, Japan.

E. The Olympic Games, which originated in ancient Greece as many as 3,000 years ago, were revived in the late 19th century and have become the world's preeminent sporting competition.



Which of the following is the FIRST sentence after the arrangement?
solution:
The given sentences can be rearranged easily if we follow the order of time as all the events in the given sentences which are given in chronological order.

The first sentence of the passage is (E), as it talks about the main topic of the passage i.e. the Olympic Games and its origin and evolution. The second sentence of the passage is (B) as it elaborates upon the history of "The Olympic Games" - how it was held during the time period - "From the 8th century B.C. to the 4th century A.D." The third sentence is (C) as it introduces "The first modern Olympics" along with the details. The fourth sentence is (A) as it perfectly follows (C) based on the order of time along with the division in the modern Olympics. Last sentence is (D) as it ends the paragraph with the 2020 Summer Olympics was held in Japan in 2021.

Thus, the correct sequence is EBCAD.


Since the correct sequence is EBCAD, the first sentence is E. Hence, the answer is option e).

question:
A sentence is given in which certain words are highlighted. Choose the option with the pair/s of words that need to be interchanged to make the sentence grammatically correct and meaningful. If no change is required, mark E as your response.

Severe heat wave conditions(A) will several (B) in many places over(C) the next couple of days, especially(D) in Rajasthan and continue (E) parts of north and central India, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) said on Sunday.
solution: Since (B) is preceded by the modal verb 'will', we need to use a verb in its root form here. The only one available is 'continue'. 'Several' can then be placed at (E), to act as an adjective for the noun 'parts'. Option D is the right answer.

question:
A sentence is given in which certain words are highlighted. Choose the option with the pair/s of words that need to be interchanged to make the sentence grammatically correct and meaningful. If no change is required, mark E as your response.

India has maintained that it will not strike (A) first with nuclear weapons but reserves (B) the right to retaliate to any nuclear strike damage (C) it with a nuclear strike that will be massive (D) and designed to inflict unacceptable against (E).
solution: It is clear that 'against' is a misfit at (E). Since the sentence talks about retaliating strongly to a nuclear strike, 'damage' fits better at (E). 'Against' can be used at (C) as we require a preposition here to tell us at whom the nuclear strike was/is directed. Option C is the right answer.

question:
A sentence is given in which certain words are highlighted. Choose the option with the pair/s of words that need to be interchanged to make the sentence grammatically correct and meaningful. If no change is required, mark E as your response.

A white airplane called Roc, which has a wingspan (A) of the length of an American football field and is fuselage (B) by six engines on a twin powered (C), took to the air shortly (D) before 1400 GMT and stayed aloft (E) for more than two hours.
solution: The sentence tells us the details of an airplane and its flight. 'Fuselage' is a misfit at B, as we need a verb in its past participle form after the 'be' form of verb (here, 'is') to form the passive voice construction. 'Powered' is the right choice at B. 'Fuselage', a noun, can appear at C. Fuselage - The main body of an aircraft. Option D is the right answer.

question: In each of the questions below, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Choose the one that is grammatically and meaningfully correct.
option_1: The company plans activities mostly on weekends and encourages employees to get their family members involvement as well.
option_2: Through this initiative, employees are encouraged to volunteer for social and environmental causes which include creating awareness on issues such as lake restoration, plant drives and solid waste management.
option_3: These activities also strengthen employee-organization relationship, and at the same time increase social coefficient by contributing towards society.
option_4: The company also partners with local non-profits for various activities, which provide its knowledge and expertise on social and environmental issues, making the employees' engagement impactful and meaningful.
solution: A- usage of 'involvement' is incorrect; it would be 'involved' to make option A grammatically correct. B- 'plant drives'- incorrect phrase usage; it would be 'plantation drives'. D- noun-pronoun mismatch- usage of 'its' is incorrect; it would be 'their' (plural) for plural noun 'non-profits'. C- contextually and grammatically correct; hence, C is the right answer.

question: In each of the questions below, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Choose the one that is grammatically and meaningfully correct.
option_1: Truth leaders have the courage to confront the meaning of existence; such leaders enter within their own hearts and souls, engage in self-analysis and connect with the spiritual force within themselves.
option_2: Becoming a true leader is about becoming a true human being; it is about choosing a life committed with spiritual growth and service.
option_3: True leadership is not acting a certain way; it is a reflection of who we are within.
option_4: Intellectually understanding service do not provide the conviction we need when we are tested, as we most certainly be, by people and circumstances.
solution: A- usage of 'truth' is incorrect; it would be 'true'. B- 'committed with': incorrect phrase usage; it would be 'committed to'. C- 'from within' would be the correct usage here. D- subject-verb agreement mismatch - 'does' instead of 'do' would be correct Also, 'will' is missing before 'be'. All of them are wrong; therefore, E is the right answer.

question: In each of the questions below, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Choose the one that is grammatically and meaningfully correct.
option_1: I found myself wasting time, often calling up people to chat, and taking tea breaks far too less.
option_2: There is always going to be the tempting to do your personal work, maybe heat up the food, or watch a video but that is unethical and unacceptable.
option_3: Forced to stay indoors after a recent ligament injury, I convinced myself that getting through the recovery period at home would be a piece of cake.
option_4: As it turned out, the only piece of cake involved was one I eat every time I wanted to take a break from sitting at my table.
solution: A- 'far too less' doesn't align with the remaining statement's tone. It would be 'far too often' to make it correct. B- the noun 'temptation' would be correct instead of 'tempting', making option B incorrect. D- incorrect tense of the verb 'eat' is used; it would be 'ate' as the entire sentence is in past tense. C- contextually and grammatically correct; hence, C is the right answer.

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with five words marked as (A), (B), (C), (D) and (E). These words may or may not be placed at their correct places. Choose the option with the pair(s) of words that need to be interchanged to make the sentence grammatically and contextually correct. If no change is required, mark 'No change required' as your answer.

The monkey (A) that was menace (B) a creating (C) in the captured (D) was neighbourhood (E) by a veterinary team.
solution:
'Was' should be followed by a participle form of the verb, either V3/V4 form. For the helping verb 'was' written in the later part of the sentence, the verb that denotes the action of the veterinary team should come at the fifth position. So, 'captured' is fit here, implying that the team captured the monkey.

The only participle form left to follow 'was' (in the former part of the sentence) is 'creating'. 'Monkey that was creating a menace' forms a meaningful phrase. So, B and C will be interchanged.

And D and E will be interchanged.

The correct sentence after rearrangement is: The monkey that was creating a menace in the neighbourhood was captured by a veterinary team.

Hence, the correct answer is option (e)

Note:

V1 -> Base form/simple form of verb, V2 -> Past form of verb (-ed form or irregular verb), V3 -> Past participle form of verb (-ed, -d, -t, -en, or -n), V4 -> Continuous form of verb / Present participle form of verb (-ing form), V5 -> Third person singular (V1+ -es or -s).

In the following question, a sentence is given with five words marked as (A), (B), (C), (D) and (E). These words may or may not be placed at their correct places. If no change is required, mark 'No change required' as your answer.

solution: The sentence is grammatically and contextually correct; hence, (e) is the right answer.

question:
Directions:

Directions : Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions that follow.

The World Bank is warning of the real danger of a massive economic downturn across the world. In a recent analysis, it warned that many countries including those in sub-Saharan Africa will be facing economic challenges due to rising food and fuel prices. At the same time, however, there is unshakeable optimism around the growth potential of African economies as a whole and specifically the digital economy. The rapid rise of tech hubs and start-ups in urban areas in sub-Saharan Africa in recent years seems to support that. Many observers have, therefore, identified the digital economy as an important long-term growth in Africa despite current global challenges.

The reality is that experiences with promoting the digital economy in sub-Saharan Africa have been mixed. Following great hopes in the promise of "digital connectivity" in the early 2000s, many scholars have observed that the ability of African businesses to turn connectivity into success in global markets has been limited. The future of Africa's tech scene is equally uncertain. Despite great potential, the tech start-up scene is underfunded, and several tech hubs have had to shut down due to bankruptcy.

The promise of the digital economy has always been a double-edged sword. Many global consulting firms and international organisations initially saw "digital connectivity" as a key driver for the future growth of African economies. Even today, there is a strong belief that you just need to have the right infrastructure in place for the digital economy to grow and create jobs.

This optimism led the Kenyan government in 2007 to define business process outsourcing as a central pillar in its Vision 2030. The assumption was that Kenya had the talent and internet connectivity to copy India's success in this business. In a similar fashion, South Africa's business leaders put their hopes in call centres, which had previously generated many jobs in India and the Philippines.

But these hopes turned out to be flawed. Digital businesses are often easy to get into but difficult to compete in - especially on the global stage. To win client contracts in a highly standardised digital business, such as call centres and tech support, you need to be scalable. Yet, to succeed with the scale you also need to be cost competitive and develop a strong reputation.



Which of the following words is similar to the meaning of 'bankruptcy'?
solution:
'Bankruptcy' means a legally declared or recognised condition of one who is unable to pay debts as they fall due. 'Insolvency' means insufficiency to discharge all debts of the owner. So, the two words can be used as synonyms of each other. Hence, the answer is option a).

'Solvency' means the state of having enough funds or liquid assets to pay all of one's debts.

'Lucrative' means producing a surplus; profitable.

'Abounding' means plenty, abundant.

'Sufficiency' means adequacy.

solution: In the fourth paragraph of the given passage, it's been stated that" South Africa's business leaders put their hopes in call centres, which had previously generated many jobs in India and the Philippines." Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

question:
Directions:

Directions : Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions that follow.

The World Bank is warning of the real danger of a massive economic downturn across the world. In a recent analysis, it warned that many countries including those in sub-Saharan Africa will be facing economic challenges due to rising food and fuel prices. At the same time, however, there is unshakeable optimism around the growth potential of African economies as a whole and specifically the digital economy. The rapid rise of tech hubs and start-ups in urban areas in sub-Saharan Africa in recent years seems to support that. Many observers have, therefore, identified the digital economy as an important long-term growth in Africa despite current global challenges.

The reality is that experiences with promoting the digital economy in sub-Saharan Africa have been mixed. Following great hopes in the promise of "digital connectivity" in the early 2000s, many scholars have observed that the ability of African businesses to turn connectivity into success in global markets has been limited. The future of Africa's tech scene is equally uncertain. Despite great potential, the tech start-up scene is underfunded, and several tech hubs have had to shut down due to bankruptcy.

The promise of the digital economy has always been a double-edged sword. Many global consulting firms and international organisations initially saw "digital connectivity" as a key driver for the future growth of African economies. Even today, there is a strong belief that you just need to have the right infrastructure in place for the digital economy to grow and create jobs.

This optimism led the Kenyan government in 2007 to define business process outsourcing as a central pillar in its Vision 2030. The assumption was that Kenya had the talent and internet connectivity to copy India's success in this business. In a similar fashion, South Africa's business leaders put their hopes in call centres, which had previously generated many jobs in India and the Philippines.

But these hopes turned out to be flawed. Digital businesses are often easy to get into but difficult to compete in - especially on the global stage. To win client contracts in a highly standardised digital business, such as call centres and tech support, you need to be scalable. Yet, to succeed with the scale you also need to be cost competitive and develop a strong reputation.



Which of the following statements is true about digital business, as per the passage?
option_2: One doesn't need to be scalable.
option_3: There is no need to develop a strong reputation.
option_4: Digital businesses aren't often easy to get into.
option_5: Digital businesses are difficult to compete in.
solution:
In the last paragraph of the given passage, it's been stated that "Digital businesses are often easy to get into but difficult to compete in - especially on the global stage." Thus, option (d) gets negated here, and (e) is the correct answer.

Options (a), (b) and (c) get negated because it's been mentioned otherwise in the last paragraph of the passage - "To win client contracts in a highly standardised digital business, such as call centres and tech support, you need to be scalable. Yet, to succeed with the scale you also need to be cost competitive and develop a strong reputation."

question:
In the question given below, two sentences are given with one blank each. From the given answer choices, choose the option which contains the word that fits in both the sentences making them grammatically and contextually correct.

(i) Dev opened his eyes as if he has been awake all along, ___ at her, full of contentment.

(ii) Half an hour later he would return, carrying a paper bag with a ______ face drawn on the front of it.
solution:
In the first sentence, a gerund would fit in to show the action performed and the second sentence demands an adjective to modify the noun 'face'.

'Smiling' is the only option that can act both as a gerund and an adjective.

So, (c) is the correct answer.

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with a phrase or idiom highlighted in bold. Select the option given below that can replace the phrase in bold without changing the meaning of the sentence and mark that as your answer.

In 1992, Parliament included Section 61A in the Act and rules validating the use of the EVM and paving way for their use in elections.
solution:
The preposition used to before a year is 'in'. Therefore, options (b) and (d) are ruled out.

The sentence means to convey that Section 61A was put in ('inserted') the 'Act' in question which validated the use of EVM after which they came into use in elections. Therefore, 'inspected' and 'instigated' are contextually incorrect words to use.

The correct sentence after replacement will be: The Parliament, in 1992, inserted Section 61A in the Act and rules validating the use of the EVM and paving way for their use in elections.

Hence, option (c) is the correct option grammatically and contextually.

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with a phrase highlighted in bold. Select the option given below that can replace the phrase in bold to make the sentence grammatically and contextually correct and mark that as your answer. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No correction required', as the answer.

Through all this uncertainty, appear a man confused what he wants.
option_1: arises the hero who was confused with what
option_2: each men arises confused about what
option_3: a woman emerged without knowing which
option_4: emerges a man confused about what
solution:
According to subject-verb agreement, we cannot use the plural verb 'appear' with the singular subject 'man'. So, the highlighted part of the sentence is incorrect. 'Confused with' and 'confused about' convey different meanings. For example:

"I always confuse Barbara with her sister", the meaning is 'fail to distinguish, erroneously regard as identical, mistake one for another'.

"I am 25 years old and I am confused about what to do in the future professionally", the meaning is 'uncertain about something'.

Option (a) is eliminated as 'confused with' doesn't provide a coherent sentence. Option (b) is eliminated as we always use a singular noun after 'each'. The latter part of the sentence uses 'he' as the pronoun. So, we cannot use 'woman' as the subject of the sentence. Therefore, option (c) is also eliminated.

Option (d) is grammatically and contextually correct.

Hence, option (d) is the correct answer.

Note:

Subject-Verb Agreement: Matching up singular or plural subjects with singular or plural forms of a verb is part of the process called agreement. This can be understood better by the examples given: - "She likes cooking." [singular subject and verb] -- "They like to cook vegetables." [plural subject and verb]

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with a phrase highlighted in bold. Select the option given below that can replace the phrase in bold to make the sentence grammatically and contextually correct and mark that as your answer. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No correction required', as the answer.

I hope my team mates and coach will not object to me playing in a defensive position.
option_2: him playing in such a manner
option_3: to my offensive style of playing
solution:
Whenever a verb is used as a gerund, the pronoun that precedes it should be a possessive determiner. Therefore, 'me playing' is incorrect. The correct phrase would be 'my playing'. So, the highlighted part of the sentence is incorrect. Options (a) and (b) are also incorrect according to this rule. The verb 'object' is always followed by the preposition 'to'. So, we can eliminate option (d) as the preposition 'to' is missing in it. Among the given options, option (c) is the correct choice.

Hence, option (c) is the correct answer.

Note:

Gerund: Gerund is a verb form that functions as a noun, ending in -ing. A gerund can be either the subject or object of a sentence in English. Example: "Everybody enjoyed her dancing and singing at the party." The words 'dancing' and 'singing' are gerunds.

Possessive Determiners/Adjectives: Words like 'my', 'our', 'your', 'his', 'her', 'its', and 'their' are known as possessive adjectives (or possessive determiners). They come before nouns and indicate ownership of the noun. Example: "The teacher asked the students to open their drawing books."

A Preposition is a word placed before a noun or a pronoun or a noun equivalent (pronoun, adverb, gerund, infinitive, adverbial clause, or any clause that can be used as the object of the preposition) and shows a relationship in space or time or a logical relationship between two or more people, places, or things in a sentence.

Examples

I. The teacher scolded the child for being late.

II. We're going to a party.

The words in bold are called prepositions because they normally take position before (pre) a noun/pronoun or a noun equivalent (pronoun, adverb, gerund, infinitive, adverbial clause, or any clause that can be used as the object of the preposition.

The noun/pronoun which is used with a preposition is called its Object.

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with a phrase highlighted in bold. Select the option given below that can replace the phrase in bold to make the sentence grammatically and contextually correct and mark that as your answer. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'no improvement required', as the answer.

My original statement has been completely distorted by the media.
option_3: Amend to address a specific concern
option_5: Reframes to emphasise a different aspect

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given, divided into five parts. The part given in bold is grammatically and contextually correct. Out of the other four parts, one part may contain an error. Mark the part having an error as your answer. If none of the parts contain error, mark 'No error' as your answer.

The first is that if interpretation (A) / is assigning a meaning, than (B) / when socially salient arrays (C) / are used, there is no (D) / interpretation going on at all. (E)
solution:
The error is in part B. 'Than' needs to be replaced with 'then'. Than is used when you're talking about comparisons; then is used when you're talking about something relating to time. Here, in the sentence, the presence of 'first' is suggestive of the fact that it is talking about things taking place in a sequential order. So, clearly 'then' is to be used.

Hence, option (b) is correct.

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given, divided into five parts. The part given in bold is grammatically and contextually correct. Out of the remaining four parts, one part may contain an error. Mark the option containing the part with the error. If none of the parts have errors, mark 'No error' as your answer.

I brought flowers (A) / for my grandmother (B) / who is admitted in a hospital (C) / and wished him (D) /to get well soon. (E)
solution:
The error is in part 'D'. The sentence talks about someone bringing 'flowers' for their ailing grandmother to a hospital. And thus, the pronoun replacing 'grandmother' [noun - feminine] cannot be 'him' [pronoun - masculine], and so it must be replaced by 'her'.

Hence, the correct answer is option (c).

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given, divided into five parts. The part given in bold is grammatically and contextually correct. Out of the remaining four parts, one part may contain an error. Mark the option containing the part with the error. If none of the parts have errors, mark 'No error' as your answer.

Goddess Sita was (A) / very sad and called an (B) / Goddess of Earth, and (C) / went back inside (D) / the ground with her. (E)
solution:
The error is in part 'B'. Indefinite article 'an' is usually used before a word/noun that starts with a vowel, and here it has been used before 'Goddess' [starts with a consonant], and so is grammatically incorrect, and thus could be replaced by definite article 'the' [there is only one 'Goddess of Earth' which makes it specific and definite].

Hence, the correct answer is option b).

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given, divided into five parts. The part given in bold is grammatically and contextually correct. Out of the remaining four parts, one part may contain an error. Mark the option containing the part with the error. If none of the parts have errors, mark 'No error' as your answer.

We was surprised (A) / to know that she has (B) / learnt to cook tasty food (C) / in her time away (D) / from all of us. (E)
solution:
The error is in part 'A'. 'We' does not agree with the verb 'was' as the correct conjugation for the pronoun 'we' for the verb 'to be' is 'we were', and so 'was' will be changed to 'were'. We infer that the 'we' will be not changed, as the correct emboldened part of the sentence tells us the author is talking in first person plural ['all of us'], and that's why 'we' will not be replaced by 'I'.

Hence, the correct answer is option a).

question:
In the question given below, a sentence is given with five words highlighted in bold. One of these five words may be either wrongly spelt or inappropriate in the context of the sentence. Find out the word, which is wrongly spelt or inappropriate, if any.

I told them (A) how to do it but I was (B) wasting my breathe (C); they went and (D) tried it their way (E) - and failed!
solution:
The word 'breathe' is inappropriately used in the given context because the sentence talks of breathing-inhalation and exhalation but 'breathe' is a verb that means taking air into the lungs and then expelling it, especially as a regular physiological process, so the noun 'breath' which means the air taken into or expelled from the lungs is the correct word to use.

Hence, option (d) is correct.

question:

question:

question: In the question given below, four statements are given. Choose the one that is grammatically and contextually correct. Ignore punctuation errors, if any. If all the sentences are incorrect, mark 'None of the sentences are correct' as your answer.
option_1: It is important to make people around you feel appreciate and valued.
option_2: If a patient is unconscious, the family can take the decision.
option_3: Hedge funds are consider risky alternative investment choices.
option_4: Education is necessary for a person's physically, mental, and social development.
option_5: None of the sentences are correct.
solution:
Option b) is grammatically and contextually correct. In option a), the verb 'feel' should be followed by the adjective 'appreciated' and not the verb 'appreciate'. Sense verbs like 'feel', 'sound', 'look', 'taste', 'appear', etc. are normally followed by adjectives. In option c), the auxiliary verb 'are' should be followed by the past participle verb 'considered' and not the base verb 'consider' because 'are' is followed by either present or past participle (here, the tense is not continuous so -ing forms of verbs cannot be used). In option d), the adverb 'physically' should be replaced by the adjective 'physical' to correctly qualify the noun 'development' because only adjectives can qualify the nouns.

Hence, the answer is option b).

NOTE:

Auxiliary verb: A verb that gives grammatical information that is not given by the main verb of a sentence. It supports the main verb. Auxiliary verbs help to form the various tenses, moods, and voices of other verbs. The principal ones are be, do, and have. Example: She will sing a song tomorrow. Here, 'will' is the auxiliary verb that supports the main verb 'sing'.

Participle: A word formed from a verb (e.g. going, gone, being, been) and used as an adjective (e.g. working woman, burnt toast) or a noun (e.g. good breeding). In English participles are also used to make compound verb forms (e.g. is going, has been). Consider the sentences given below:

Dancing at the party, the women fell on the ground.

Encouraged by her parents, Rita went on to pursue her passion.

The highlighted word in the first sentence is of the form Verb + ing and is used as a present participle. It is used to denote an action that is going on or incomplete or imperfect.

The highlighted word in the second sentence is of the form verb + ed. It is used as a past participle. It denotes completed action or state of the thing spoken of.

A past participle ends with the following: -ed, -d, -t, -en, or -n.

One should take great care and never get confused between a gerund and present participle. They use the same forms but perform different functions: a gerund is a verbal noun, while a present participle is a verbal adjective.

question:
Match the statements from Column 1 with Column 2 and find which of the following pair of statements given in the options make sense contextually and grammatically.

Column 1Column 2
A. All agencies should use modern technology to inform citizens aboutD. of earthquakes led to the city's abandonment.
B. It was very considerate of Harold to send hisE. benefit others, we are more resilience and motivated.
C. Research shows that when we think about how our actions canF. mother-in-law a bouquet of flowers on her birthday.
solution:
The correctly matched pair is: B-F.

B-F: Statement B praises Harold for being considerate. ('Considerate' = 'thinking of other people's wishes and feelings'). Statement F states the reason behind such appreciation.

C-E: Statements C and E form a contextually coherent but grammatically incorrect sentence. Statement C introduces a research. Statement E completes the sentence by mentioning the findings of the aforementioned research. The noun 'resilience' is incorrectly used to qualify the pronoun 'we'. Pronouns are qualified by adjectives. The adjective 'resilient' should replace 'resilience'. ('resilience' = 'strong enough to deal with illness, a shock, change, etc.').

Statements A and D fail to form any meaningful sentence.

Hence, the answer is option c).

question:

question:

question:

i. Access to the means of using the internet, such as owning a computer, __________ an important role in household choices of fixed or mobile data services.

ii. A remarkable fact about Shakespeare's ___________ is that scholars can't agree on how many he actually wrote.
solution: Sentence i) requires a verb, while ii) requires a noun. Amongst the given options, only d) fulfils these conditions. Options a) and b) are irrelevant in the i) blank and c) does not fit in the ii) blank. Option d), 'plays' means both a piece of writing that is intended to be acted in a theatre or on radio or television (fits in (ii)), and the fact that it acts as a deciding factor (fits in (i)). Hence, d) is the correct answer.

question:

i. Soils are like sponges with a ______________ of pores that allows water and air to freely enter and escape.

ii. Office conferences and gatherings are viable opportunities to _____________.
solution: Statement i) requires a noun as the blank is preceded by an article 'a', while ii) requires a verb (infinitive construction). b) is irrelevant in i); c) and d) do not fit in ii); option a) fits in both the blanks suitably and gives out grammatically and meaningfully correct sentences. 'Network' as a noun means a large system consisting of many similar parts that are connected together to allow movement or communication between or along the parts, or between the parts and a control centre and as verb means to meet people who might be useful to know, especially in your job. Hence, a) is the correct answer.

question:
In the question given below, two sentences are given with one blank each. From the given answer choices, choose the option which contains the word that fits in both sentences making them grammatically and contextually correct.

i. In the new norm of climate change, we need to understand the behaviour of soils in terms of more _____________and much wider variations in water content.

ii. A ____________ scrutiny of the political ads on social media platforms is highly sought after.
solution: Options b) and c) are irrelevant and do not give out coherent meaningful sentences, hence, these are rejected. Blank i) requires an adjective to qualify the noun 'variations' and ii) requires an adjective which would qualify the noun 'scrutiny'; option a) fulfils these conditions simultaneously and brings out coherent sentences. 'Frequent' means happening often. Hence, (a) is the correct answer.

question:
In the question given below, two sentences are given with one blank each. From the given answer choices, choose the option which contains the word that fits in both sentences making them grammatically and contextually correct.

i. The __________ of global auto giants does not seem to be working in India, as they continue to struggle with a market share of 5 per cent or less in the world's fifth largest passenger vehicle market.

ii. This creates an automatic priority system that will help kick start your To-Do ____________.
solution:
The first sentence conveys that auto giants aren't performing well in Indian market. The second sentence talks about creation of a system to start a process.

Mojo (magic charm, influence, spell) would lend appropriate meanings to both the sentences (charm of global auto giants in I, and 'To-Do Spell' in II); hence, (a) is the right answer.

Other options do not lend appropriate meanings either one or both the sentences; hence, they are eliminated.

question:
In the following questions two equations numbered I and II are given. You have to solve both the equations and choose the correct option.

I. x2 +8x -9 = 0

II. y2 +25y +136 = 0
option_5: x = y or relationship cannot be established
solution:
From equation I:

x2 +8x -9 = (x + 9)(x -1)= 0

=> x = -9, 1

From equation II:

y2 +25y +136 = (y + 8)(y + 17) = 0

=> y = -8, -17

X = -9X = 1
Y = -8x < yx > y
Y = -17x > yx > y

So, relationship cannot be established between x and y

question:
In the following questions two equations numbered I and II are given. You have to solve both the equations and choose the correct option.

I. x2 +33x +252 = 0

II. y2 +15y +56 = 0
option_5: x = y or relationship cannot be established
solution:
From equation I:

x2 +33x +252 = (x + 12)(x + 21)= 0

=> x = -12, -21

From equation II:

y2 +15y +56 = (y + 7)(y + 8) = 0

=> y = -7, -8

X = -12X = -21
Y = -7x < yx < y
Y = -8x < yx < y

So, x < y

question: The path outside a circular plot is 77 cm wide and the area of the park is 6.16 m2. 4 poles are fixed on the outer side of the path of the circle, then find the distance between two poles.
solution:
Area of the park = 6.16 m2

Side of the park = (6.16 * 7/22) = 1.4 m

Radius of the park with path = 1.4 + 0.77 = 2.17 m

Perimeter of the park with path = 2 * 22/7 * 2.17 = 13.64 m

Number of poles = 4

Distance between two poles = 13.64/4 = 3.41 m

question: The height of the base of the cylinder is 5/9 times of the radius of the cone and radius of the cylinder is 3/5 times the height of the cone. If radius and height of the cone are 63 cm and 50 cm respectively, then what are the volume of the cylinder?
solution:
Radius and height of the cone are 63 cm and 50 cm respectively.

So, height of the cylinder = 63 * 5/9 = 35 cm

And radius of the cylinder = 50 * 3/5 = 30 cm

Hence, volume of the cylinder = 22/7 * 30 * 30 * 35 = 99000 cm3

question: Age of Kapil is 13/11 of the age of his younger brother Sonu and Raju is 8 years younger to Sonu. If the ratio of age of their father and mother is 10 : 9 and father is 46 years older to Raju. Find the average age of father and mother if the average age of family of all 5 members is 35.2 years.
solution:
Let the age of Kapil and Sonu is 13x and 11x respectively.

Age of Raju = (11x - 8)

Age of their father = 11x - 8 + 46 = (11x + 38)

Age of their mother = (11x + 38) * (9/10) = (9.9x + 34.2)

Average age of the family = [(13x) + (11x) + (11x - 8) + (11x + 38) + (9.9x + 34.2)]/5 = 35.2

=> 55.9x = 111.8

=> x = 2

Required average = [(11x + 38) + (9.9x + 34.2)]/2 = [(20.9 * 2) + 72.2]/2 = 114/2 = 57 years

question: A fruit box contains 4 apples, 2 oranges and 5 pomegranates. 2 fruits are drawn at random. What is the probability that none of the fruits drawn is pomegranate?
solution:
Total no. of fruits = 4+ 2+5 =11

n(S) = no. of ways of drawing 2 fruits out of 11

=11C2 = 11*10 / (2*1)=55

Let E = event of drawing 2 fruits, none of which is pomegranate

n(E) = no. of ways of drawing 2 fruits out of 6 fruits

=6C2 =6*5 / (2*1)=15

P(E) = n(E) / n(S) =15 / 55 = 3/11

question:
Directions:

Directions :Study the data carefully and answer the following questions:

From a shop, customers purchased three kinds of shirts such as Cotton shirts, Rayon shirts and Linen shirts. 1500 customers purchased these three kinds of shirts from the shop.

The ratio of number of customers who purchased Cotton shirts and Rayon shirts but not Linen shirts, customers who purchased Cotton shirts and Linen shirts but not Rayon shirts and customers who purchased Rayon shirts and Linen shirts, but not Cotton shirts are 2: 3: 6. The number of customers who purchased all three kind of shirts is 5(1/3)% of total number of customers and number of customers who purchased Cotton shirts and Linen shirts, but not Rayon shirts is 4% of total number of customers. The number of customers who purchased only Linen shirts is 20 more than 4 times the number of customers who purchased three kinds of shirts and number of customers who purchased Cotton shirts is equal to the number of customers who purchased Linen shirts.



How many customers purchased Cotton shirts?
solution:
Let areas in Venn-diagram be a, b, c, d, e, f and g.

a + b + c + d + e + f + g = 1500 ---(1)

e: d: f = 2: 3: 6

Let e = 2x, d = 3x and f = 6x

The number of customers who purchased all three kinds of shirts is 5(1/3)% of total number of customers

So, g = 16/300 * 1500 = 80

The number of customers who purchased Cotton shirts and Linen shirts, but not Rayon shirts is 4% of total number of customers.

So, d = 4/100 * 1500 = 60

And, d = 3x = 60

=> x = 20

So, e = 40 and f = 120

The number of customers who purchased only Linen shirts is 20 more than 4 times the number of customers who purchased three kinds of shirts.

So, c = 20 + 4 * g = 20 + 4 * 80 = 340

The number of customers who purchased Cotton shirts is equal to the number of customers who purchased Linen shirts.

So, a + d + e + g = c + d + g + f

=> a + e = c + f

=> a + 40 = 340 + 120

=> a = 420

From equation (1), we get

420 + b + 340 + 60 + 40 + 120 + 80 = 1500

=> b = 440


The number of customers who purchased Cotton shirts = 420 + 40 + 80 + 60 = 600

question: A boat covered 'X' km downstream in 25 hours, while it came back to the starting point in 125 hours. If the distance is increased by 200 km, then the time taken by the boat downstream and upstream is increased by 5 hours and 25 hours respectively. Find the total actual distance covered by the boat.
solution:
Let the speed of a boat in still water and the speed of a stream be 'K' km/h and 'L' km/h respectively/

downstream speed = The speed of a boat in still water + The speed of a stream

= K + L km/h

Upstream speed = The speed of a boat in still water - The speed of a stream

= K - L km/h

Time = Distance/ Speed

25 = X/ (K + L)

X = 25 * (K + L) .... (i)

125 = X/ (K - L)

X = 125 * (K - L) ....(ii)

From (i) and (ii)

25K + 25L = 125K - 125L

100K = 150L

2K = 3L

K = 3L/2 = 1.5L

5 = 200/ (1.5L + L)

2.5L = 40

L = 16

K = 16 * 1.5 = 24 km/h

question: Two persons A and B together can finish 66(2/3)% of work in 6 days and A, B, and C together can finish 33(1/3)% of same work in 4/3 days. Find the time taken by C alone to finish 50% of the total work.
solution:
Time taken by A and B together to finish 66(2/3)% of total work = 6 days

Time taken by A and B together to finish the complete work = 3/2 * 6 = 9 days

Time taken by A, B, and C together to finish 33(1/3)% of total work = 4/3 days

Time taken by A, B, and C together to finish the complete work = 3 * (4/3) = 4 days

Let total work = LCM of 4 and 9 = 36 units

Part of work done by A and B together in 1 day = 36/9 = 4 units

Part of work done by A, B, and C together in 1 day = 36/4 = 9 units

Part of work done by C alone in 1 day = 9 - 4 = 5 units

Time taken by C alone to finish the whole work = 36/5 = 7.2 days

Time taken by C alone to finish 50% of the total work = 7.2/2 = 3.6 days

question: Priya's monthly salary is 40% less than Amir's monthly salary and the ratio of expenditure of Amir and Priya is 7: 3. If Amir's monthly savings are Rs. 5000 and Priya saves 44(4/9)% of her monthly salary, then what is the Priya's monthly salary?
solution:
Let Amir's monthly salary = Rs. 100x

And, Priya's monthly salary = 100x * 60/100 = Rs. 60x

And let expenditure of Amir and Priya are Rs. 7y and Rs. 3y respectively.

Priya savings = 60x * 4/9 = Rs. 80x/3

=> 60x - 3y = 80x/3

=> 180x - 9y = 80x

=> 100x = 9y

=> x = 9y/100

And, 100x - 7y = 5000

=> 100 * 9y/100 - 7y = 5000

=> 2y = 5000

=> y = 2500

So, Priya's monthly salary = 60 * 9 * 2500/100 = Rs. 13500

question: The ratio of the first number to the second number is 6: 5 and the ratio of the first number to the third number is 2: 1. If the average of 80% of the second number and 3/2 times of the third number is 68, then find the value of the first number.

1st number2nd number3rd number

5X * 80/100 + 3X * 3/2 = 2 * 68

4X + 9X/2 = 136

17X = 272

X = 16

Hence, the 1st number = 6 * 16 = 96

solution:

Thus, C > N holds false and C > R holds false.

If we replace % with and with , the equation will be: R N < B V C.

Thus, C > N false true and C > R holds false.

question:
Two statements numbered I and II are given below. You have to decide whether the data provided in the statements are sufficient to answer the question.

K is the wife of M. N is the only brother of M. Q is the wife of G. How is G related to P?

Statement I. P is the wife of N.

Statement II. G is the son of M.
option_1: If the data in both statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question
option_2: If the data either in statement I alone or in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question
option_3: If the data in both statements I and II together are necessary to answer the question
option_4: If the data in statement I alone are sufficient to answer the question while the data in statement II alone are not sufficient to answer the question
option_5: If the data in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question while the data in statement I alone are not sufficient to answer the question
solution:
K is the wife of M. N is the only brother of M.

From I alone:

P is the wife of N. Q is the wife of G.

So, it cannot be determined how G is related to P. So, statement I alone is not sufficient.

From II alone:

Q is the wife of G. G is the son of M.

So, it cannot be determined how G is related to P. So, statement II alone is not sufficient.

From I and II together:

Q is the wife of G. P is the wife of N. G is the son of M.

So, G is the nephew of P. SO, both the statements together are necessary.

question:
Directions:

Directions : Fourteen person are sitting in two parallel rows. Persons - B, C, D, E, F, G and H sit in row 1 facing towards the north direction and persons - L, M, N, O, P, Q and R sit in row 2 facing towards the south direction.

B sits fourth from one of the ends and faces N. D sits second to the left of B. Two persons sit between N and O, who sits immediate to the right of L. P faces G. Neither L nor N is neighbour of P. One person sits between P and R. H sits third to the left of B. C sits immediate to the left of F. Neither Q nor R faces F.



If M is related to F, L is related to D, in the same way, who among the following persons is related to E?
solution:
Fourteen person are sitting in two parallel rows. Persons - B, C, D, E, F, G and H sit in row 1 facing towards the north direction and persons - L, M, N, O, P, Q and R sit in row 2 facing towards the south direction.

B sits fourth from one of the ends and faces N.

D sits second to the left of B.

Two persons sit between N and O, who sits immediate to the right of L.

P faces G. Neither L nor N is neighbour of P.

One person sits between P and R. So, case 1 is invalid.

H sits third to the left of B.

C sits immediate to the left of F.

Neither Q nor R faces F.

Therefore, the final arrangement is:


M faces F. L faces D. In the same way, Q faces E.

question:
Directions:

Directions : Fourteen person are sitting in two parallel rows. Persons - B, C, D, E, F, G and H sit in row 1 facing towards the north direction and persons - L, M, N, O, P, Q and R sit in row 2 facing towards the south direction.

B sits fourth from one of the ends and faces N. D sits second to the left of B. Two persons sit between N and O, who sits immediate to the right of L. P faces G. Neither L nor N is neighbour of P. One person sits between P and R. H sits third to the left of B. C sits immediate to the left of F. Neither Q nor R faces F.



____persons sit between E and F.
solution:
Fourteen person are sitting in two parallel rows. Persons - B, C, D, E, F, G and H sit in row 1 facing towards the north direction and persons - L, M, N, O, P, Q and R sit in row 2 facing towards the south direction.

B sits fourth from one of the ends and faces N.

D sits second to the left of B.

Two persons sit between N and O, who sits immediate to the right of L.

P faces G. Neither L nor N is neighbour of P.

One person sits between P and R. So, case 1 is invalid.

H sits third to the left of B.

C sits immediate to the left of F.

Neither Q nor R faces F.

Therefore, the final arrangement is:


Two persons sit between E and F.
